description: From Middle English floteren, from Old English floterian, flotorian (“to float about, flutter”), from Proto-Germanic *flutrōną, frequentative of Proto-Germanic *flutōną (“to float”), equivalent to float +‎ -er (frequentative suffix). Cognate with Low German fluttern, fluddern (“to flutter”), German flittern, Dutch fladderen; also Albanian flutur (“butterfly”). More at float.

entries.meaning: The act of fluttering; quick and irregular motion.
An abnormal rapid pulsation of the heart.

(uncountable, aerodynamics) An extremely dangerous divergent oscillation caused by a positive feedback loop between the elastic deformation of an object and the aerodynamic forces acting on it, potentially resulting in rapid structural failure.
(Britain) A small bet or risky investment.
examples: So with his victory odds currently at 14/1 or 3/1 for the podium, he's still most certainly well worth a flutter  […]

entries.meaning: A hasty game of cards or similar.
(audio, electronics) The rapid variation of signal parameters, such as amplitude, phase, and frequency.

verbs.description: flutter (third-person singular simple present flutters, present participle fluttering, simple past and past participle fluttered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To flap or wave quickly but irregularly.
(intransitive) Of a winged animal: to flap the wings without flying; to fly with a light flapping of the wings.

(intransitive, aerodynamics) To undergo divergent oscillations (potentially to the point of causing structural failure) due to a positive feedback loop between elastic deformation and aerodynamic forces.
(transitive) To drive into disorder; to throw into confusion.
(intransitive) To be in a state of agitation or uncertainty.
(espionage, slang) To subject to a lie detector test.
examples: This was the first time that Nosenko had been subjected to a lie detector — or what the CIA called fluttering. The Soviet Union did not use such devices for interrogation.
